nobody governs. Multiple private companies competing to find best way to score it. Just like search engines ranking by keyword.
14/ End of storm. What are your thoughts on building a journalism reputation system? Anyone trying or tried to build it? Ideas welcome. Thx!
13/ People will share and find what they want. And that is a good thing overall.
12/ Takes great hubris to think we know what is best for someone else and should choose what they can and cannot see.
11/ People may not want the quality (by whose definition?), and not care about the scores. So be it.
10/ Help keep things in check (quality reporting vs feeding people's addictions like fear, gloating, mob mentality, etc).
9/ Temptation is great to sensationalize/exaggerate/rush for more eyeballs/attention. Reputation score would be a natural counter balance.
8/ Mis-aligned incentives in journalism have existed for a long time. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propaganda_of_the_Spanish%E2%80%93American_War …
7/ And those most willing to exaggerate/sensationalize/rush out a story/race to the bottom for clicks.
6/ A journalism reputation service feels like a good business idea. Let's see a leaderboard of most trusted journalists and publications.
5/ Social media apps can incorporate these scores if valuable to users, similar to rottentomatoes movie ratings showing in iTunes.
4/ An independent company (consumer reports for journlism) seems best. Let multiple private companies compete to see who scores best.
3/ Social media should empower anyone to share what they want - not censor (based on what rules? who decides? too many shades of grey)
2/ Doesn't make sense to me that social media sites should curate, or play judge and jury. Impossible to win, and slippery slope.
1/ Idea i'm most interested in to solve fake news is a reputation system for publications, journalists, and articles.

labor demand is only inelastic because many costs are fixed in the short-run.
no, it doesn't. You're assuming people - especially employers - don't have choices.
it may just take some time for their full array of choices to become available.
you're just cost-shifting the subsidy onto the employer, which will eventually have an impact on labor demand.
Of course one difference is who bears cost: cost of artificially high wage imposed on employer, cost of subsidizing wage born by taxpayer.
But again, it's important to realize that what's true in the short run may be very wrong in the medium or long run.
In other words, if raising minimum wages doesn't reduce amount of labor demanded, providing food stamps, EITC, etc has no impact either.
But note: to extent it is true, labor demand would be inelastic in both directions, affected neither by wage subsidies nor by wage hikes.
That may indeed be at least partly true in the very short-run, due to fixed costs. Less true in long-run as fixed costs become variable.
Now some - including economist - will argue that employers' demand curve is inelastic, the demand for workers doesn't change with wages.
And you've got different policies posing contradictory answers to that question, pushing in opposite directions.
The basic question in both cases is: would you rather have fewer people working for more, or more people working for less?
Raising the minimum wage does the same thing - in the opposite direction.
In other words, they shift wages and jobs ALONG the employers' demand curve for labor, they don't move the curve itself.
They're really more about managing the labor supply curve than they are about influencing the demand curve.
Both, in effect, are efforts to reduce the marginal cost of working vs not working.
People who argue that food stamps subsidize low-wage employers never seem to ask the same question about the Earned Income Tax Credit.
it's a question of how you cure it: getting to the economic root of the matter, or trying to paper it over?
